It’s not the first case of anthropomorphization of our insides and using human body as a setting for story. While the idea is interesting, Hataraku Saibou got much more popularity than I expected. After watching it, I still don’t fully understand reason behind it. No, it’s not bad anime, but it absolutely failed at what I expected from a title using such setting due to two things:
 1. We got a lot of info dumps that should’ve been better integrated into actions instead of having narrator explain everything - I feel that part got better later.
 2. Way too much action. For the most partthis anime felt like Monster of the Week kids show.


Despite those major flaws, I consider it a pretty fun anime, mostly thanks to characters. They are very one-dimensional and simple, but I enjoyed seeing their actions and interactions, even if they were a bit cheesy at times. Their personalities made them very easy to get attached to. And while majority of villains were boring, maniacally cackling nobodies, there still were some nice surprises among them.

Cute characters design, colourful art and casual use of blood splatters helped a lot with comedy and gave Hataraku Saibou a light and relaxed feeling. I really appreciate that even in serious moments this series newer got too dark or edgy, keeping the overall nice atmosphere.


I’d also like to praise music in this anime - and to be exact, good usage of background music to add to some scenes. Many series fail at it, or don’t even attempt, which automatically puts Hataraku Saibou at “above average” level.


One more thing I need to mention is educational value: there is pretty much none. Please stop. The only thing I learned from this anime are english and japanese names of things I knew from middle school biology. I’m all for learning while having fun, but people try to sell it as something very educative, which is an overstatement.



In the end, I’m a bit disappointed, but I don’t regret watching it. It was a fun anime despite its flaws and I’m sure everybody will be happy with a change of pace Hataraku Saibou offers among all the usual settings.

I just wish we got more platelets.

Let me start off by saying, I love anatomy!!! One of my favorite things in the world is the study of the human body, and how it works.
The story is really good, the show uses characters which are simple, and defines everything in a simple yet accurate way, so you can fully understand what goes on. They make it easy for you to keep track of whats happening even if your not interested in the backstory of how everything works.
The art is good, its no godlike art style, but its kind of like above middle class.
Sound idk the sounds are made.
Characters are cool, but theytry to add like a love interest thing with some of the main important cells, and tbh it kind of ruins it for someone who wants to learn, but its good for people who do not just watch the history channel for fun.\n\n
Enjoyment, I enjoyed it.\n\n
Overall would recommend to anyone who likes science, would recommend to anyone taking a science class such as Chemisty/Anatomy/Forensics, would maybe recommend it if you just like learning, and would probably still recommend it even if you vomit at the fact that some crazy anime stuff is happening inside you.

Pros:
- Personification in anime done correctly.  (Also, does the concept of Osmosis Jones but better).
- Surprisingly educational.  Would work good as an interesting tool to help high school students learn the names and functions of blood components.
- Holds the audiences attention good.  Doesn't feel boring for each episode.
- Creative world building
Cons: 
- I know it's not supposed to be extremely realistic, as it is still animation, but some of the diseases presented as enemies are WAY deadlier in real life than are represented in this show.  While tons of people can, and have, survived such things as cancer, hemorrhages, etc.The way they are presented here makes it seem like the body can fight these off without hardly any effort when in fact it doesn't. \n
- Some other minor inconsistencies (I.E. how is the person all these cells are in not dead by now?  How are all these cells surviving so long? etc.).  \n\n
Overall:\n\n
This was fun.  As someone who grew up loving science and loved shows like the Magic School Bus as a kid, this was right down my alley.  Body swapping, and anthropomorphism are two common tropes in entertainment I never get tired of, and seeing Japan take on these kinds of tropes always adds something different and original from what I expect.  If you're like me and enjoy this kind of mildly educational, but fun, stuff, this is the series for you.

Pretty much every edgy insecure young male that watches anime knows Studio David Production from one particular show I don't even think it's worth to mention because it's so overhyped in my opnion, but I learned to get to know Studio David Production's work for the first time with the anime 'Cells At Work!'.
I always was kinda interessed in how your body worked ever since I was a kid, so I wasn't a stranger for the concept. Since we have a Japanese older anime called 'Seimei no Kagaku: Micro Patrol' that I have seen as a kid not even once but twice dubbed on akids channel in my country. Be sure not to get lost while your delivering your oxygen. 1 2 3 4, We Are Cells at Work!



Story: 8/10 (Very Good)

This anime is about you. More to be precise your cells in your body. Every cell in this anime are anthropomorphic: From the red blood cells to the cute little platelets the internet all pretty much heartly welcomed. Each has their own job in the body to keep your body alive. 24 hours a day & 365 days a year. In this anime we follow one of the red blood cells named AE3803 (let's call her Red Blood Cell-chan for now), is new on her job and has trouble navigating through the body. A white blood cell, U-1146 (We're going to call him White Blood Cell-kun for now), bumped into Red Blood Cell-chan. He decides to help Red Blood Cell-chan while on duty to stop bacteria and germs that doesn't belong in a healthy body.


While the idea of anthropomorphic cells isn't new and been done a lot of times already and even done here in the west, it doesn't mean you can't enjoy this show. This show is probably the best anime created for Summer 2018 and if I think about it even perhaps for the year 2018 in my eyes if I really want to crown Cells at Work! the title "Anime of 2018".


Art: 8/10 (Very Good)

The artstyle and the animation is very lovely and I really think it does combines very well with the action and humor you will get on your plate. Even though it's very wierd to see blood within blood. How does that even work? Let's classify and file it under as just "anime physics"?


Sound: 9/10 (Great)

Same goes for the music: No doubt about it; great. The opening song is very cheerful and I ever since I heard the opening song for the first time, I always felt like wistling along. The voice acting were done great as they really suited the charathers very well.


Character: 9/10 (Great)

With every kind of cell being an character and there being so many different types of cells in your body, there are a ton of characters who make multiple appearances, but it isn't too hard to distinguish the main characters. You have Red Blood Cell-chan, a young girl wich is a redhead who gets lost all the time, White Blood Cell-kun, an odd strange fellow for sure, but he has a secret softy side, the cute little platelets who are perhaps the most adorable characters of this anime and perhaps the main reason why you should check out this anime in the first place since they are voiced by Maria Naganawa (She also voiced Kanna from Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid, mind you). We have Macrophage, a deadly cell who kills cold blooded bateria with a smile, Memory Cell being the treu book worm of the show and the Killer T Cells that fit very wel being portayed. All these characters are really joyfull to see interact with eachother.


Enjoyment: 9/10 (Great)

Not only is this anime really charming and the humor gave me some good chuckles, I really liked they also have putted some info about the charathers you will see trough the series. Some people may dislike this, but since I'm a huge science nerd, I really enjoyed it they gave you information trough the episodes. I even learned a new small fact thanks to this show I didn't knew!


Overall: 9/10 (Great)

This is not only a really good anime for anime fans, but I also think this is just a good show for everybody young and old. Even for persons that don't watch anime on a highly basis, I highly recommend to watch this anime if you want to understand the cells in your body a bit more. Maybe just a minor nit-pick that there was only one episode that felt a little off below the normal quality you get to see as the show, but that's maybe just me. Cells At Work! still is in my point of view deserves the title "anime of 2018" and is a must-watch! If you still haven't taken care of your body yet, just give this anime a chance. No doubt you'll change your mind.

TL;DR: Risking itself in doing multiple tasks, but it turns out becoming an anime that you can't miss out!!!
I remembered the days I was watching shounen anime and most of them are often really shallow and repetitive, I know someone may disagree with my point of view, but most shounen anime doesn't really impress me much, as main characters are being ignored and they just focus on one or two characters, the storytelling is even most likely omitted, they just focus on one theme then all episodes are all similar, which is really boring to me. I really want to try to find a goodshounen anime, but I can't.


Cells at work, on the other hand, is really impressive. It has satisfied me more than I expected. This is not really a typical educational anime, which each episode is the narrator talking about how each cell functions in different circumstances. They're all inserted with different personalities and the varieties of this show has become one of the main features of this anime.


+Many character varieties

+Many story elements (comedy, shounen, passions)

+being educational in an interesting way


-Perhaps some episodes need more explanations 

-Due to its varieties, viewers may not enjoy it entirely


Generally, the characters have many varieties, we have red blood cell, who is acting like clumsy, she seems to be very useless in most situations and requires help from others. White blood cell, which seems to be the one who is very helpful and energetic and able to know clearly how the body works.These are just two examples from the anime and I can already write a few sentences about them. You can see that each character is being organised thoroughly to fit into the personification. You might ask about that will there be any inconsistencies with its educational theme? I can tell you the answer is clearly no. Each character is still referring to their functions according to Biology, they are just being added some flavours to become more interesting to look at and I can say that it's not easy to do that. It's indeed really risky to do two tasks at the same time, but cells at work has nailed it at the end.


Furthermore, some characters even have a whole episode to talk about their past events, while being educational. For instance, there's an episode about red blood cell and white blood cell being taught by Macrophage, how they face the obstacles and challenges among bacteria. Most shounen anime are unable to do that, they just focus solely on their themes, like Food Wars, which is about Souma cooking dishes and facing obstacles. It's entertaining enough for people who like insane cooking challenges, but what about people who don't? What about for people looking for an interesting story? It's kinda questionable in my opinion (you can refer to my previous review for more details), but cells at work can do so. Each episode has shown enough character personalities and stories, while being educational in a comedic way. It doesn't really solely focus on its educational values, but focus on many other aspects as well, clearly the writers have put many efforts in this anime. Hence, it's more enjoyable in my opinion.


Perhaps in some situations, I think some episodes that Cells at work needs more elaboration, like the episode about fever, the problem hasn't fully solved yet, but it ends up in a rush and moving on to the next disease, maybe because of the episode limit. Also, as it has many varieties to offer, viewers may not enjoy all the elements that this anime offered due to their preferences. However, I think at the end at least you will get something enjoyable apart from its educational values and I think this is a kind of anime that everyone would enjoy watching it.


The animation is in a simple style and it's crafted perfectly to fit into the main theme. Maybe if more colour visuals are used, it'd be more better. Voice actors are great, here we have Hanazawa Kana, voiced as Red Blood cell and platelet voiced by Naganawa Maria, which is the voice actor that has also voiced as Kanna from Dragon Maid and they all fit into the characters well. Sound effects are used in many scenes. The op by characters and the ed by ClariS are also very great to listen as well.


Story:9/10 (S)

Animation:8.5/10 (A+)

Sound:9/10 (S)

Character:9/10 (S)

Enjoyment:8.5/10 (A+)

Overall: 8.85/10 (A+)

This show should not be viewed for its story.  It is a personification of our bodies that is brimming with character.  On the surface, Hataraku Saibou is very much a bland edutainment series, but in some moments you can see a lot of humanity.  
Overall, I would recommend this to anyone who is suffering in high school biology class and anyone who is simply looking for a good Killer T(ime). 
Story:
Hataraku Saibou does not have the most interesting story.  You can easily generalize it with this formula: 
1. Everyday life ruined by wound.
2. Red gets scared.
3. New biological problem introduced
4. Whiteand gang fix problem.\n
5. The end\n\n
For better or for worse, Hataraku Saibou's strength does not lie with it's story, but rather with its characters.\n\n
Art:\n
David Productions has down a wonderful job designing the characters of the local inhabitants within us.  It is easy to identify who is what based on their clothing, expression, and physical build.  The world is watercolored and has a friendly atmosphere which nicely contrasts with the rough dystopian-like setting whenever problems occur.  \n\n
Sound:\n
The opening music is so catchy.  There is a sense of teamwork and harmony that rides with the upbeat rhythm of song.  While it's OST isn't the most unique or memorable, it does a great job setting the tone.\n\n
Character:\n
Again, it is easy figuring out who is what based on design and personality.   Small details can reveal a lot of character for some characters.  For example, Red's cowlick can reveal that she is in fact a sickle cell, which explains her clumsy nature.  There is a surprising amount of character development for a edutainment series.  Notable characters include Killer T, Helper T, and Cancer.\n\n
While trope-y the very characterized personalities really help bring out a sense of a diverse, yet harmonic world.

Biology wasn't my favorite subject in school. Except for the reproduction chapter nothing stook out for me as particulary interesting and the only things I remember from it are some random trivia. I now regret never continuing with that class, because Hataraku Saibou has me interested in my body all over again. Put on your cap and grab your oxygen, this is my review of Hataraku Saibou.  
Story: 9/10
This anime is about cells in your body. Every cell in this anime is an anime character: From the red blood cells to T-cells. Each has their own job in the body to keepit alive. One of the red blood cells, AE3803 (let's call her red blood cell-chan for now), is a rookie and has trouble navigating through the body. A white blood cell, U-1146 (I hate these names. Now he is white blood cell kun), coincidentally bumps into red blood cell-chan. He decides to help red blood cell-chan with navigating the body while trying to defeate all kinds of bacteria. 


While the idea of personificating cells isn't new, going this directions is pretty damn creative. It is probably one of my favorite settings in anime so far, even if the world building can get repetetive at times which I will explain later.  


Art: 7/10

The artstyle and the animation are pretty good.. but nothing that spectacular. The action scenes are most of the times slideshow images which isn't bad, but it feels there was low-effort put into it. It is still really nice to look at it.  


Sound: 7/10

Same goes for the music: Pretty good, but nothing noteworthy. The opening is very charming but admittendly not the kind of song that I would put on loop and the ending is great but it isn't ClariS best work.  


Character: 8/10

With every kind of cell being an character and there being so many different types of cells in your body, there are a ton of characters who make multiple appearances, but it isn't too hard to find the main characters. You have red blood cell-chan, a cheerful girl who gets lost all the time, white blood cell-kun, a pretty strange fellow but is still enjoyable, the platelets, the most adorable characters of this year and the main reason why you should check out this anime, Macrophage, a deadly cell who kills bacteria with a smile, and Killer T, a very aggresive cell. All these characters are really fun to see interact.  


Enjoyment: 8/10

Not only is this anime really fucking charming and the humor hilarious at times, it also was really informative and I learned a lot about cells, like how cells come to earth and that apparently T-cells exist. Actually, I didn't know the majority of the cells in the anime that they exist. Sadly, the information that you get from this anime is also the biggest downside. It can sometimes feel that they tell you way too much and it can ruin the pace of the anime at times. The anime can also repetetive at times because of its episodic nature. Still, I really enjoyed my time with this anime.  


Overall: 8/10

This is not only a really good anime for anime fans, but I also think this is just a good show for everybody, even non-anime watchers. This is a good contender for a starter anime and I highly recommend to watch this if you want understand cells in your body more.

Please note this review is intended to be read by those that have finished watching Hataraku Saibou and while care has been taken to minimise story related spoilers there may still be spoilers within character analysis.  You have been warned. 
Based off a popular manga of the same name Hataraku Saibou which is also known by its English name Cells At Work is a comedy and shounen genre anime that gives us the rather unique opportunity to see what will happen if the many cells that live within our body were to be given not just the appearances of human beings but also uniquepersonalities of their own and allow us to see the kind of struggles that they go through as they fulfill the various functions that they have been taught within our bodies.


This idea of converting the many cells that we know exist inside our bodies but we know little about in actuality into humanoids that have differing personalities and allowing us to see the kind of struggles that they put in as they set about the task of managing our bodies day in and day out I felt was an interesting premise as it proved to be not just a fascinating experience but also one that was educational as well due to the knowledge that we gain from seeing how they deal with various situations that happen to the human body. The first episode did an excellent job of not just introducing to us the large and wonderfully designed world of the human body but also in introducing a host of characters that will serve to be great leads as we get to see their struggles as they alongside billions of other cells work hard to keep our body moving. 


Taking place deep within the human body that serves as the main stage of the series Hataraku takes place in a large and well-designed town whose various districts form each of the bodies major organs that are linked to each other via countless blood vessels that within the series take the forms of countless long passageways. Each organ within the series in addition to being seen as its own district also has unique themes that are tied to it, for example, the heart the bodies most important organ is seen as a giant shrine while the origin of the cells the Red Bone marrow is seen as a school.


The overall story that makes use of such a rich setting follows the life of two characters the rookie Red Blood cell a clumsy and naïve cell that has a uncanny ability of always getting lost and running into invading bacteria and germs and the white blood cell her opposite number who while an efficient killer of invaders and germs is actually a soft-spoken and gentle person by nature that while unrecognized and looked down upon by other cells still does his best to protect them from harm. While polar opposites in personalities these two soon strike up a strong friendship and assist each other as they not just go about their jobs of keeping the body running and healthy but also learn to grow and develop as individuals as they confront and overcome one threat after another. Joining them in this unknown war inside us is a host of characters and allies that include the Calm and patient Helper T cell, the proud and boisterous Killer T cell, the quiet but logical Regulatory T cell, the brave but lonely Eosinophil, and the gentle and cheerful Macrophage. Together these cells while varying greatly in temperament and motivation must learn to work together as they protect not just their homes but also us from a wide range of wacky germs and bacteria that seek to break into our body and cause havoc.   


U-1146 


U1146 voiced by veteran voice actor Tomoaki Maeno of Kiznaiver and Log Horizon fame is one of the main characters of the series and one of Red Blood Cells friends within the series. Better known as White blood cell within the series it can be seen that white blood cell is a stoic, hardworking and dependable person that while acknowledging the views that other cells have for him and his kin still approaches his assigned role with motivation and tenacity. While very loyal to his job as one of the bodies foremost defenders it can be seen that white blood cell while intelligent can also be somewhat slow to react to new changes in the situation which is seen in a number of scenarios where the germs and bacteria gain the advantage due to their unorthodox tactics. While seemingly brooding and not one for small talk it can be seen that this is but merely his surface personality as beneath this it can be seen that White blood cell is someone that is surprisingly kind and caring to others and can be quite honest with his own opinions. 


However, while honest it can be seen that White blood cell is also someone that can be overly harsh on himself at times shown when he blames himself for not reacting fast enough to a crisis or to save an innocent cell from harm. However, rather than letting this cause doubt within him this instead has the opposite effect as it serves to provide White blood cell with the extra motivation that he needs to fulfill his duties and protect his fellow cells better. 


AE3803 


AE3803 voiced by veteran seiyuu singer Kana Hanazawa of Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei and Infinite Stratos fame is one of the main characters of the series and is the main protagonist of the series. A rookie Red blood cell that had just started on the job some weeks ago from the onset it can be seen that Red blood cell was someone that was earnest, hardworking and cheerful and was someone that tried to do the best that she can in the roles that she had been assigned to. However, within the series, this is offset by her clumsy and ditsy nature and her seemingly uncanny ability of being able to get lost on the most simple of routes. An ability that also had the unfortunate effect of leading her to locations where germs and bacteria would arise from too often hilarious results. However, despite her seemingly series of misfortunes, it can be seen that Red blood cell is someone that really loves her job and similar to her counterpart White blood cell see’s it as an important duty. As a result of this and also because of her friendly nature it’s perhaps unsurprising that Red blood cell not only managed to forge a strong friendship with White blood cell that not only allowed both to make their first friends but also allow each to find strength from seeing each other’s actions and develop into better cells that are more effective at their roles than their pasts selves. 


While ditsy, clumsy and evidently someone that had a poor sense of direction at the beginning of the series as the series goes on this begins to change. While very loyal to her job as the series goes on and Red Blood cell realizes just how vital her role as a RC cell is to the body she gradually realizes that getting scared of every little thing isn’t just lowering her efficiently but also that of the countless other cells that work alongside her as well and as a result not only becomes braver but also willing to improve herself by both learning her routes and trying to do tasks herself a development that I felt was a welcome one and one that showed just much she had learned from seeing how hard the other cells were working. 


Helper T cell 


Helper T cell voiced by veteran voice actor Takahiro Sakurai of Food Wars and Grancrest fame is one of the main support characters of the series and is one of Red Blood and White Blood cells allies within the series. A member of the T cells subtype of white blood cells Helper T cell from the onset can be seen to be someone akin to a general that’s commanding a frontline not just in terms of attitude but also in terms of regalia and station as he commands the defense from a space that can be seen to be a close match to a military command center. A calm composed and intelligent person by nature Helper T cell as benefiting someone that’s akin to a general is someone that’s patient, perceptive and fast thinking and can be seen to be someone that’s capable of seeing the larger picture. Unlike his subordinate killer T cell Helper T cell is someone that is seen to value not just teamwork but also efficiently as well and as a result, can be seen to have a rather turbulent but also amusing relationship with him something that I feel was quite funny considering the differing personalities that they have. While a logical and sometimes cold person by nature Helper T cell is undoubtedly one of the bodies most vital cells in their endless fight against the bacteria and the germ.  


Killer T cell


Killer T cell voiced by veteran voice actor Daisuke Ono of Durarara and Attack on Titan fame is one of the main support characters of the series and is one of Red Blood cell and White Blood cells allies within the series. A member of the T cells subtype of white blood cells like his superior Helper T cell Killer T cell from the onset can be seen to be someone that’s loud, confident and proud of his status of being a part of the elite anti bacteria division. As a result of this Killer T cell is someone that can be quite intimidating to others and inadvertently causing most cells to view all white blood cells as psycho’s that are obsessed with strength and thus cells to avoid. As a result of this personality, it's perhaps unsurprising that Killer T cell is someone that’s quick to anger and doesn’t like asking others for help even if the situation is outside of his ability to deal with. Indeed, it can be seen that unlike the majority of other cells Killer T cell is someone that seems to view friendships with disdain. 


Despite his intimidating and loud nature, it can be seen that Killer T cell is someone that’s dutiful, responsible and is very proud of his job and surprisingly is someone that can respect those that have a strong motivation to fight and willing to offer them help and advice when needed. While certainly loud and brash Killer T cell I thought was the type of cell that they needed to act as the backbone of the frontline. 


Regulatory T cell 


Regulatory T cell voiced by veteran seiyuu singer Saori Hayami of Owari no seraph and Darling in the Franxx fame is one of the main support characters of the series and is an important ally to White Blood Cell and Red Blood cell. A member of the T cells subtype of white Blood cells Regulatory T cell from the onset can be seen to be a calm, composed and quiet person that performs her role within the series with both professional grace and effortless efficiently something that stands her in good stead as the second in command to her superior Helper T cell. While professional and calm Regulatory T cell is also someone that’s patient and perceptive easily able to determine the main roots of a problem and suggest countermeasures to her superior. Ironically despite being the second in command of the defense effort, she has her hands full with keeping the likes of killer T cell and Helper T cell from taking each other on a role that will no doubt give others a headache. 



Eosinophil 


Eosinophil voiced by veteran seiyuu Mao Ichimichi of Digimon Tri and Youkoso fame is one of the main support characters of the series and is one of White Blood cell and Red Blood cell’s allies within the series. A type of white blood cell Eosinophil from the onset is shown to be someone that’s brave, tenacious but also quiet. While the great majority of white blood cells within the series are shown to be looked down upon it can be seen that this has had a much larger effect on her as it ensured that she had few if any friends and thus making her both lonely and quiet and ensuring that she has very low self-esteem. While acknowledging her lack of strength when compared to other immune cells like Macrophage and being especially sensitive to being called weak by others it can be seen that Eosinophil is still someone that will work hard to protect her fellow cells and willing to step up to face dangerous threats no matter the odds arrayed against her. This shows not just her responsible nature but also how dedicated she is to her job even if others view her with nothing but disdain. 


While originally someone that had very low self-esteem that’s seems out of place for an immune cell Eosinophil’s gradual overcoming of her fears within the series and in the process winning the respect of her fellow cells I felt was done well within the series and showed that sometimes the strongest cells are those that are able to step up at the right moment and do their assigned role without fear. 


Macrophage 


Macrophage voiced by veteran seiyuu Kikuko Inoue of Fullmetal alchemist Brotherhood and Rosario to Vampire fame is one of the main support characters of the series and is one of White Blood cell and Red Blood cell’s allies within the series. A type of white blood cell Macrophage from the onset can be seen to be someone that is calm, positive, kind and gentle and is someone that’s more in line with a mother figure than anything else. An intelligent, fast thinking, cheerful and perceptive person by nature Macrophage is someone that evidently loves her job as while allowing her to take down evil invading germs and bacteria also allows her to interact with and help raise new cells into their assigned roles. As a result of this varied skill set and unique personality, it can be seen that Macrophage not only has the respect of her fellow cells but also the utter fear and despair that the many bacteria and germs have for her something that is quite surprising for a single cell. 


The character of Macrophage I felt was quite the interesting one that was helped by not just her versatility but also of the fact that her unique mannerisms only served to highlight that while graceful and beautiful she was also someone that was capable of wrecking great havoc on any invaders with her prized hatchet that takes advantage of her impressive strength. Seeing an assassin also take up the role as a cleaner and childcare worker I felt was quite intriguing.  



AMV 


In terms of animation, I felt that the character designs for the series characters were pretty well designed and animated within the series. Each of the characters within the series which within the context of the story are types of cells that were given human form I felt while unique in appearance also matched well with the duties that they play within the body via their unique quirks like for example the red and white outfits that are worn by Red and White blood cells who deliver oxygen and handle intruders, the office like attire of Regulatory T cell who deals with trouble between cells and the military like outfit worn by Helper T cell. The character design for Macrophage in particular I felt was quite unique as it gave not only a unique appearance to her, but it was also one that matched well with the fact that she was a hybrid cleaner and assassin in function as well. In terms of locations I felt that the series did a really good job of transforming the inside of the body into something that most humans would recognize which is a town and I felt that it also featured quite a variety of terrain that not only gave each section of the body a unique theme but also in a way that made sense to the viewers. The combat animations within the series of which there were many I felt was pretty well done that was helped greatly by both the fluidity of the animations but also by the creative depiction of the many types of germs and bacteria that the immune cells must deal with every day.



Music wise I felt that the series OST did an excellent job of providing good background music to the many scenes within the series being calm and peaceful when everything is going well and dramatic and tense when things go south. The series made use of one opening and ending theme which was Mission Ken Kou Dai Ichi which was sung by Kana Hanazawa, Tomoaki Maeno, Daisuke Ono and Kikuko Inoue who voiced the characters of Red Blood Cell, White Blood Cell, Killer T and Macrophage respectively and CheerS which was sung by ClariS. While the opening theme had the positive and cheerful tone that gave the feeling that it will be another cheerful day at work the ending theme gave the impression that it was thanking us for our hard work. Both of these themes I felt matched well with the series main subject of cells defending us day in and day out from evil bacteria and germ and a war that we didn’t know existed within us.


In terms of voice acting, I felt that the voice cast of the series did an excellent job of portraying their assigned characters whether they were main ones or supporting ones. In particular I felt that Kana Hanazawa, Tomoaki Maeno, Takahiro Sakurai, Daisuke Ono, Saori Hayami, Mao Ichimichi and Kikuko Inoue who portrayed the characters of Red Blood cell, White blood cell, Helper T cell, Killer T cell, Regulatory T cell, Eosinophil and Macrophage respectively all did an excellent job portraying their assigned characters. In addition, while I didn’t cover them I also felt that Maria Naganawa and Aya Endou who portrayed the important characters of the adorable platelet and the ever-helpful Sempai Red Blood cell also did a great job portraying their respective characters. While she doesn’t have a character of her own within the series I felt that the series narrator veteran seiyuu Mamiko Noto also did an excellent job of not just introducing us to the various organs within the body but also in explaining the functions that the various cells, bacteria and germs have in an easy to understand manner. This I felt was helped greatly by Mamiko Noto’s prided calm voice. 


Overall conclusion 


Overall Hataraku Saibou I felt was quite the fascinating anime that had among its strong points a unique premise, entertaining story, well-designed characters, excellent voice acting, creative character and enemy designs and well-designed combat scenes. 


The first thing that comes to mind when looking at what Hataraku Saibou is that unlike most animes this season it feels less of anime but more like an educational program that aims to teach its audience about the various cells that exist within the body and how they each contribute in helping to protect us from the many bacteria and germs that we encounter each day. In an anime season in which we have seen samurai heroes, vampires disguised as coffee makers and demon lords that are more cute than threatening such a fresh change of subject and premise I felt was not just surprising but also incredibly refreshing as well. 


The overall premise of the series is naturally the unseen war that rages beneath our very skin and one that pits the bodies countless cells against the countless invading bacteria and germs that enter the body every minute of the day. This premise I felt was quite interesting as until now very few animes feature the human body as its main setting and as a result being able to see inside a world that we humans seldom get to see and understand unless of course you’re a doctor was something that was fascinating to me. This premise was helped greatly by the fact that each of the cells that live within the body were not just given unique appearances but also in the fact that the series takes great pains to ensure that each cells function within the series is accurate and explained in a easy to understand manner and thus matching well with the premise that this anime’s main purpose rather than show how cool cells are which they are is to educate the viewers on how they work together inside us to protect our bodies from harm.  


The overall story of the series I felt made great use of the series premise by not just showcasing the unique characteristics and personality of each cell but also of the duties that are unique to them by making use of a great variety of bacteria and germs that invade the body. While the series made use of the common villain of the week formula that we so often see in both animes and tv shows the series also took great care to make these relevant to the series premise by not just introducing us to the nature of the germs and bacteria that invade the body in an episode but also of the overall threat that they pose to the body. This way of both showing us the immediate short-term threat and the effects that it has on the larger picture I felt was well done and helped greatly by the large variety of illnesses that the studio managed to squeeze in. 


Additionally I also felt that the series did an excellent job at showing the kind of decision making that the cells make as they deal with major decisions and I felt it was nice that we got to see not just what the overall strategists like helper T cell would do but also how the frontline immune cells like White blood cell, Macrophage and Killer T cell would react when sudden threats that are different to what they encounter in their daily activities erupt suddenly. This aspect I felt served to remind people that the defense of the body is a job that’s fulfilled by countless cells that all work together for one purpose which I felt matched well with the series main purpose. 


Overall Hataraku Saibou was an anime that I really enjoyed and was definitely one of the best animes this season and was one that was not just entertaining but also educational as well. As a final score I would say that Hataraku Saibou easily deserves a final score of 10/10.

Cells at Work (Hataraku Saibou) is a solidly entertaining summer TV series.
It is often touted as the Japanese answer to Osmosis Jones and Once Upon a Time...Life, and both comparisons are accurate.
Although it is an educational series at heart, Cells at Work is also quite entertaining. It functions as a battle shounen sprinkled with facts about the human body and a dash of characterization here and there.
The main character is a ditzy but well-meaning Red Blood Cell, and her counterpart is the stoic, germ-slaying White Blood Cell. Their interactions are surprisingly compelling for two anthropomorphized cells, and the extended cast of characters is also good.
TheJojo-esuqe Killer T Cells and the adorable Platelets are the most memorable supporting characters so far, but many of the additional cells are given a chance to shine over the course of the series. 


Each episode has featured a new enemy in a "monster of the week" format, and new cells or bodily systems have been concurrently introduced.


The episodic nature has worked well so far, although a sinister enemy introduced this week (episode 6) could end up being the big bad for several episodes.


To summarize, Cells at Work is an entertaining anime. Its audience is primarily students and teens, but the show's cast of characters is varied and endearing enough to appeal to a broader group of fans. You don't have to be a biology expert to enjoy this fun, action-filled, and occasionally dark summer anime.


Ratings: 


Story: 7/10. No over-arching plot, but the developing cancer cell subplot is quite interesting.


Art: 8/10. Colorful, good action scenes, distinct and unique character designs.


Sound: 8/10. Good sound effects and soundtrack. 


Character: 8/10. A fun cast filled with Jojo references, moe characters, and a cute MC.


Enjoyment: 7/10. Light summer fare that actually teaches you something.


Overall: 7.5/10. Nothing groundbreaking, but it is an entertaining battle shounen with a unique setting and memorable characters.

Before you say this anime doesn't deserve a 10, shut up, this is a preliminary review, let me have this pls.
Best way I can describe this beautiful anime is Inside Out meets One Punch Man, which to me instantly spells jackpot.
You see, there's two things in this world I adore. The first one is anthropomorphic animals/objects/things. The second one is Biology jokes and references or Science jokes in general. This show covers both.
From the cute concave hat of Erythrocytes to the "KILL" spelling hats of CTLs (Literally called Killer T Cells), the attention to detail is astonishing. That's basically the main reason I love thisshow so much. It's like it was tailored made for Science geeks.

Let me put it like this; I firmly believe this is an anime you could show your college professors and NOT feel embarrased about. That's super rare.


The art is pretty good, the story is unique aswell, and the musical score is on point, but what's most important is that this show is flooded in creativity, well executed creativity. At the end of the day that's what matters the most, at least for a comedy in my opinion.


No one wants to hear a joke they've been told a thousand times already, that's exactly why this anime works, because where else can you find something like this?

The closest thing I can think of is those old Biology cartoons they used to show us in school. In a way this is exactly that, but more complex.


It's as if those elementary school cartoons somehow got adapted to the level many of us are currently at, which feels refreshing. As if they had grown with us.


Personally I wouldn't use the show as a teaching tool though. Jokes hit much better when you already understand what they're about.


That's not to say the general public should be discouraged from watching it. I think what you need in order to understand this show is AT MOST a highschool diploma, which most people here already have, so if you have the time, definitely give it a watch.

Hataraku Saibou or Cells at Work is an educational anime which is actually a bit surprising given the amount of gore involved.
There isnt too much of a story to it, each episode is generally episodic where most of what happens in prior episodes doesnt matter. Each episode explains how things works in the body and has the body's cells protect it from germs, viruses ect. For the most part it revolves around a Red blood cell that often gets lost trying to do her job and is a magnet for germs'viruses and a white blood cell that tends to always appear at the nick oftime and massacres germs. What little story there is revolves around the interaction between the two and stopping the Villain of the episode. There might be one or two two part episodes in the short series.


Art work is nicely done. It doesnt blow you out of the water but it looks good and I cant say I noticed any parts where the quality dropped like in other anime when they tend to show characters at a distance. 


Character wise there is a some development and the characters are likeable. They feel like real people with personalities even if it is not to a deep extend.  I found it enjoyable as a short anime. I wouldnt go as far as recommending it but if you are looking for something to watch it might be worth adding this to your list.

You know what this show reminds me of? Saturday Morning cartoons. Completely cheesy, sometimes nonsensical writing. Animation that definitely cuts corners sometimes. Heavy handed lessons. And yet, I enjoyed it very much.
I have actually been reading the manga before getting into the anime, and honestly i prefer the manga. The pacing in the manga just flows better, and the art looks better too. I was slightly disappointed in how much the anime relied on recycled shots and still images. The manga has the educational bubbles that you can read if you want to get an understanding of the biological basis, which I found to beinformative while not too intrusive. In the anime, however, the entire story pauses while a narrator reads this bubble, which often wrecks the pacing. I feel the show would have served better to let the narrative point to the science without stopping to fully define all the terms.


The plots and villains of each episode vary from intriguing to old school dumb, like the fact that every villain monologues and is evil for the sake of being evil. Occasionally, the show provides an intriguing narrative and antagonist, such as the episode that deals with cancer cells. The tropes and narrative conveniences reminded me very much of Saturday Morning Cartoons, and despite my criticisms, I often had a smile on my face and felt vaguely nostalgic.


One bright spot in the production in my opinion was the soundtrack. The orchestral music was lush, but also often playful. It may have not have always been used in quite the right moment  narratively, but the music itself was well made. Also, the use of traditional Japanese drums to represent the heartbeat was I think a brilliant move. It got my heart pumping!


So yeah, the show isn't really that amazing, but it is fun!

this show honestly made me appreciate my body more (specifically the cells that comprise it)
i feel happier after watching Hataraku Saibo. i wake up each morning thanking my cells for allowing me, through their hard work, to experience life in this world.
as for the show itself... it was a joy to watch and learn from! hopefully someday i will be able to share it in a biology class or something. the music was nice. the sound effect were nice. the artwork was nice. the characters were nice. while it is a good idea to watch it as a full series, i feel as if itwould be fine to catch an episode or two out of order due to the fact that there are repeated explanations of each type of cell and the roles they play in our bodies.\n\n
i can imagine a creature from another planet watching this show as serious education lol\n\n
thank you aniplex and whoever else contributed to this project!!

Summer 2018 is undeniably one heck of a ride with all of the most hyped and anticipated anime be it sequels or original adaptions but there is one particular unique anime that stands out from the rest of the titles and that is Cells at Work! or also known as Hataraku no Saibou. Japan never fails us in providing us anime that contain personifications of inanimated objects or living things like Houseki no Kuni (anime about gems) and Kemono friends (anime about wild animals) and both of them were breaths of fresh air in the modern anime industry and Cells at Work is no execption.


STORY : (7)


the rest of the plot takes place in a personified human body where billions of trillions of anthropomorphic cells are living there, working all day without taking a break at all just like our real life body cells. it also focuses on two main characters, the red blood cell who always get lost whenever she goes and a relentless white blood cell who always gets his job done fighting invading pathogens.  to be specific there is almost no plot in the entire episodes each of the episodes tells a single story about each of the cells specific functions and what they contribute to the human body. there are some laughs here and there but the most crucial is how the narrator explains the functions of the cells whenever they make their first appearance to the point that it already becomes an educational tool for those who dont have any background in biology which is a good thing indeed as a lot of anime nowadays are lacking it. 


ART : (8)


the series was made by a studio that Jojo fans are familiarized with, David Production. While most of their works are not really that groundbreaking, the visuals in this anime is actually decent. i really love how bright the settings are not to mention the graphical expressions of the characters as they interact with each other. Unfortunately, the background settings are not really that great. its average at best with all of the dull looking buildings which can be an eyesore to some people. one thing that i want to praise is how accurate they designed the pathogens. for instance, the bacterium actually do have those tentacles-like parts which are something that are attached to real life bacterium. with all of these amazing details and how each of the anthropomorphic cells look very different from each other, the studio did their best. 


SOUND : (8)

im going to start with the opening and ending songs. for starters, the OP song is quite catchy to listened to although some people may actually dont like it that much. What amazed me is that the seiyuus are actually the ones who sang the song. as for the ending, i feel like it is charimastic and relaxing in the sense of like after all of the chaotic moments in a particular episode (yeah im not kidding) and this song plays, it will put a smile in your face. and most crucially, the voice actors notably the famous Kana Hanazawa who played the role of Erythrocyte chan she really did an absolutely splendid job heck some people solely watched cells at work just because she played a role of the main character it shows how many people adored her voice although she appeared in dozens of anime that it some people got bored with it. the other seiyuus also performed a great job potraying each of the characters professionally. 


CHARACTER : (9) 


if there is one thing that im going to praise a lot,it would be the cast of the cells mainly Miss Red Blood Cell chan. Kana Hanazawa is perhaps the best seiyuu which fits her clumsiness and overreactions most of the times. Some might found our cute RBC quite a bit annoying with her trademark of being lost in almost every episode but that is how she is. Mr White Blood Cell on the other hand, is the complete opposite of her. Being one of the few blood cells in the human body's immune system to annihilate any invading pathogens. He can be quite serious and ruthless most of the times but from the inside, he's actually kind hearted always protecting RBC from the shadows. Other than that, probably the most lovable character by the fandom is of course adorable little Platelet chan,another important cell which helps to coagulate wounds. although her appearance is not that frequent but whenever she did, it always sent smiles to our faces. Of course there are other great characters as well i can gurarentee that you will find them likeable. 


Enjoyment : (9)


Like i said earlier at the begining of the review, this anime is a breath of fresh air that not only it serves as a form of entertainment but at the same time viewers can also learn a bit of two about the characteristics and functions of the cells which these anthropomorphic cells professionally displayed in the show. Unfortunately, the pace can get a bit repetitive in nature due to the fact that almost every episode begins with pathogens invading the body, a new cell is introduced to destroy them and the end. there are however some episodes that change the pace which makes it less daunting to watch especially the last episode which in my opinion is very dark and gritty. but overall Hataraku no Saibou is a fantastic anime which even non anime fans will find it enjoyable. if you dont have anything to watch and looking for something fresh and new also if you are passionate in biology just like i am, then this show is worth the watch!


Overall : (8.6)

Cells at work is carried heavily by cute and interesting character designs which are "human" representation of cells, ie the adorable platelets. However, midway through the show, there are glaring issues with the anime that become really apparent that ruins the entire experience. 
Characters: 
The cells in the show are depicted as humans which their attire and personality derived based on whatthe cells do. Killer T and white blood cells(wbc) are arrogant killing machines, killer T being more arrogant wheras wbc are more endearing with the red blood cells(rbc). Platelets are extremely adorable but why are they depicted as kids? Subsequently, the "plain" cells and rest of rbc are assholes who go beyond what backdrop characters do. An example of this is at Ep 4 which sees the introduction of kousankyuu which, according to the show, kills parasites. The ep starts of with kousankyuu protecting a rbc from germ but failed to kill it since thats not her specialty. The other rbc and "plain" cells are at the  back shittalking about her inability. You cant help but go "why?" at that scene as that was literally someone risking their life to protect another but to be looked down due to her inability. Though the ep ends with her redemption, you cant help but feel that kousankyuu should have let those who looked down on her in the first place to die.\n\n
Specific examples aside, one glaring issue for me was the use of CG in the show. The rest of the rbc who are travelling along 3803 are obviously CGs but they are done so poorly that they appear to be moonwalking forward while pushing their carts. Also there will be specific scenes where you can see several of the background rbc having identical movement.\n\n
Art: \n
Im gonna skip out commenting on how the character designs and environment are indicative of what they are suppose to represent since 1) im shit at biology, 2) Im not an art expert. However, i will say there are several scenes where the art is extremely lazy which makes it particularly disappointing considering how much hype this show's gotten (Ep7 21:40, 3803's head is scaled disproportionate to how she is in the immediate next frame 21:45"s still image.)\n\n
Story:\n
It borders between slice of life and educational, however, there are world building concepts that seem to fall apart if you think about them for more that 3 seconds. Ep 3 ending shows that the platelets have created a net to close up an abrasion wound and the ep ends with 3803 and 1146 being stuck to the sticky net along with other cells to create a scab. I never took biology as a subject so i could be wrong but isnt a scab something that falls off as "dried blood" when the wound has recovered? Platelet mentioned this at the end of the ep which based on that would mean that 3803 and 1146 will be expelled out of the body when the wound is closed up. Might be nitpicky but this small things kinda ruins the viewing experience. Again, i could be entirely wrong and even if im right, the issue can be fault on its source material, the manga.\n\n
Conclusion: \n
I came to this show excited, with all the fan art about the characters and how adorable platelet is in those small clips you see on the internet. However, beyond the cute character designs, hataraku saibo is plagued with multiple issues that stops it from being a classic. The issues i've highlighted are minor and probably nitpicky but are things that can be ratified if the team behind it put just a bit more effort and attention to detail to make it better. At the end of the day, it boils down to a neat concept that has gone to waste due to the accumulation of minor faults.

This is my first review. May contains spoiler.
Initially, I think this anime has a unique premise. It must be great. It's not, but enjoyable enough.
Story 5/10:
This is basically an educational anime about blood cells in our body. However, while it is mostly accurate, some of them is not. For example:
1. How can erythrocyte and eosinophil meet again?
2. Why does erythrocyte carry nutrient?
3. Anisakis is too powerful.
Another one is that when it is true in the real body, it makes no sense in the story, like:
1. Lack of red blood cell causes winter? (Because heat travels via blood by convection better than via cells by conduction,since there is no blood fluid here, this reason cannot be used for this anime)\n
2. Where do medicine, transfusion fluid, and other blood cells come from? (By going to the doctor and get a recipe for medicine and transfusion, but nowhere are we given the reason why in this anime) This is the classic example of deus ex machina.\n
3. How can transfusion fluid save the day? (In this anime's setting, it will either causes a flood or not enough to combat dehydration)\n
4. Why is the hassle of training a white blood cell when it will just be helper T cells? (Helper T cells don't fight here, although the test will be very important in the real body)\n\n
Art 7/10:\n
Good but generic. Nothing to comment.\n\n
Sound 8/10:\n
I can't comment about the sound, but the OP is great.\n\n
Character 6/10:\n
Generic character, with cells with the same type have similar personality. The only exception is erythrocytes and (to an extent) eosinophil. Macrophages would be great if it is just for one cell instead of entire macrophages. Also, the cancer cell is good.\n\n
Enjoyment 7/10:\n
Despite that, this anime manages to attract my interest for its funny moments (although too few for a comedy), heartwarming moment, and one great arc (cancer arc).\n\n
Overall 6.6/10.\n
If you have time to waste, I recommended watching this anime. However, be sure to double check everything that comes from this anime. Also if your anime taste is refined (as I am not), you may dislike this anime.

Osmosis Clones: An Unserious Review
There are plenty of unusual demographics in anime. There are mecha fans, hopeless romantics, hentai addicts, so on and so forth. Cells At Work tailors to a very specific demographic indeed: the shounen-fan-medical-student.
Cells At Work tries its hand at fusing comedy with shounen tropes. Although neither of these do anything outstanding, they gel together well. The comedy is enough to make you smile without breaking your ribs, and the fight scenes are typical bloodfests. But the real quirk here is the science behind it all. It’s easy to see that the writers have done serious research into the field. The anthropomorphisedbiological accuracy is enough to make a pathologist squeal in delight. Proper cell names are used, entire episodes are based around physiological conditions, and the presentation grabs the attention of viewers who couldn’t give two dendrites about biology.


As clever as the underlying facts are, they can obstruct the narrative from time to time. Whenever something new and interesting happens, the action will freeze to make time for an explanation of what this cell is, and why it’s doing what it’s doing. Call me a purist, but I’d rather not have my epic shounen fights paused so that Lovely Narrator Lady can explain why Staphylococcus Aureus is a nasty pathogen. “Show-don’t-tell” is a staple of good storytelling – one that Cells At Work sometimes forgets. Even then, the narrative doesn’t have mush to boast about anyway. It’s heavily serialised with minimal continuity and frequent flashbacks. While not necessarily bad, there are a few missed opportunities for decent character arcs.


Speaking of characters, they’re the real heart (haha) of the show. Our cellular main characters Red Blood Cell and Neutrophil (White Blood Cell) make for some entertaining viewing. Neutrophil is the classic badass soldier with a heart of gold, while Red Cell is made entirely of sugar, haemoglobin, and waifu material. I do wish Red Cell were a little less ditsy, and that Neutrophil didn’t have to run to her rescue every other episode, but the chemistry (enough of these puns) between these two is enough to make up for it. This show’s characters, both main and supporting, are consistently engaging. Episode 7 had me feeling actual human emotions. For a villain, no less. That hasn’t happened since Thanos.


Cells At Work has plenty of errors in its genetic makeup, but its core skeleton is solid and reliable. It has heart. It has nerve. It has brainpower to match. If you’re looking for a red-blooded shounen anime with high levels of dopamine, direct your retinas no further than this show.


On a related note, I think I have a pun infection.

Well, how can I say this, Cells At Work is by far the most educational anime I have seen so far in my history of watching anime. Not to mention its the first time I've seen such show focuses mainly on the interior of the human body, other than Ozzy and Drix. The whole concept concentrates primarily on immunology and injury-response of cells in our body, and yet we haven't seen its involvement in reproduction. It is fascinating how directly pathology/biology explanation can be made so interesting and provides valuable information. 
Story: 8 
In the early half of the season, each week we get tosee how different cells respond to different bacterial invasion into our circulation and organs. Each week we received new lectures on how each cells function (& formed) within the specific area of the body/infection. It fascinates me how narrative the information was provided and application of their duty to the disease. Not to mention we get to witness amazing relationship development between cells to add an entertainment touch to it. Also, comedy was added to provide laughter rather than the boring teaching of functions. The story was directed well to captivate dramatic scenes such as fights between bacteria, and yes, cancer itself. The final episode was icing on the cake as we witness how determined the cells are to keep the body alive.     


Art: 8 

Fantastic character design especially with the details of the clothing of macrophages and T-Cells. The splashing of blood from bacteria characters was unique and well animated to provide suspense of its eradication. The scenery was magnificently enlivened to represent the interior of the human body parts in a fictional way.  


Sound: 9 

The opening was quite catchy to get the audience excited for the episode with the characters saying its title. Additionally, provides good tunes to create energy in the music. As for the ending, nothing beats ClariS, as a big fan of their music they did not disappoint with the beautifully written piece to provide cheerful rhythm to end the episode. As for background music, especially during fight scenes, was well adapted to the environment to elicit the right feeling to the scenes.  


Character: 9 

My girl Macrophage is by far my favourite as she is deadly and beautiful with a deathly smile to make my day. Platelets were the stand out favourites for the anime community with the endless memes, clips and merchandises off for grabs, especially with the talent of Naganawa, her amazing childish voice made Platelets the most loveable characters of this series. The RBC and WBC appeared every episode to provide a comedian and romantic development as the season progresses, not to mention they knew each other since their development in the bone marrow. The T-Cells offer much more brutality feeling to them, which reflects how T-Cells are supposed to be in our body.  


Enjoyment: 8 

Saying that I enjoyed this show is an understatement. Not to mention I upload weekly reaction videos on YouTube on this fantastic series. Each week provides different challenges which make this show the most enjoyable and reflects how educational-flow as the season progresses as each week offers new valuable information to fill my knowledge gap. A good mix of action and comedy, and yes kawaii platelets scenes, sums up how amazing this series is. Providing a bit more social development will push its ranking.  


Overall, I highly recommend watching this anime as it provides valuable biology information weekly, and guaranteed fictional description to reinforce the learning.

So what happens when you put education, anime, and Japan's constant need to make everything cute to the point that they anthropomorphize everything from animals to navy vessels all together?  This.  This is that result.  
Story:
In the human body, there are trillions of cells that work in all hours of the day to protect the body that they're in to ensure its survival.  But given the body's apparent fragility in terms of how permeable it is and the very nature of nature itself causing mini mistakes within an organism's body, the life of the cells is constant battle against those that threaten the body they inhabit.
Structuredas an episodic series, each episode of Cells at Work features the body where our resident red blood cell AE3803 encounters various pathogens and bodily conditions that make her otherwise normal workday as a red blood cell of transporting nutrients and oxygen to various cells around the body a living nightmare as the constant threat of death is almost always right around the corner.  As a result, Hataraku Saibou is one of those shows that you watch for its novelty, being a creature/situation of the week kind of show with a lot of charm to its quirky and unique setting, especially since the show teaches a lot about basic circulation/blood biology with a few intricate concepts and fun facts thrown in to mesh with the narrative.


Overview:

+ VERY unique show

+ Educational!


Characters:


AE3083 is primarily the cell that the show focuses on, being a red blood cell with terrible direction sense (ironic for a cell whose job is being a biological deliveryman) and is usually in trouble since she's a target being the kind of cell made to help other cells prosper.  Wanting to be actually good at her job, the series doesn't really do much to develop her character, but instead gets lost and ends up as being involved in the various incidents the show presents by virtue of just being there.


The other primary character is U1146, a neutrophil (common white blood cell) that's usually first on the scene whenever a rogue antigen shows up on screen.  Compared to his compatriots in the cast, U1146 is the primary director for the most of the show's more 'humanizing' moments, as his desire to understand and get to know the various cells around him who by their nature, also work just a single job and do that job their entire lives shows up from time to time and gives some surprising depth to a primarily comedic/education based series.


Various other cells like the macrophages, dendrite cells, brain cells, killer T cells, B cell, and the ever loved Platelets (who are portrayed children due to their smaller size compared to other blood cells) add in a diverse and memorable cast because everyone gets their moment in the spotlight thanks to a convenient narration by Mamiko Noto to describe their function, made even more apparent when the show tackles a situation where their specific functions/job is needed in order to solve the situation at hand.


Overview:

+ Surprisingly a good amount of character depth

+ Extremely memorable cast of characters


Art:


Made by David Production, aka the 'Jojo's Bizarre Adventure' company, Hataraku Saibou is a pleasant mix of cute, funny, and incredibly violent, as the life of AE3083 is filled with lots of running away/avoiding the massive amounts of problems that the body she lives in encounters, before the white blood cells come in and slash away at their foes, spilling massive amounts of blood before their fallen foes bear comedic X's over their eyes.  


What's more than the show's bright colors and pleasant to look at style is the structure of the world, since the body we're shown is structured like a human society, with many organs portrayed as unique buildings, blood vessels as long sidewalks that all of the blood cells use to traverse, and the cells as people who live within the apartment blocks that represent their location in the body.  It's one of those things that's more genius the more you think about it, due to the idea that a body is just a massive society of smaller beings is made into a literal sense.  


Overview:

+ Hilariously easy switches between violence and comedy

+ Very creative world


Sound:


"Mission! Ken・Kou・Dai・Ichi" sung by the seiyuus of AE3083, macrophage, U1146, and Killer T cell is a very memorable song, being an upbeat almost band-like song with a catchy beat that replicates the quirkiness of the show to a tee.  Very rarely do I find seiyuu songs as memorable as this, and this is definitely one of the better ones in recent memory.  By comparison, its ED sister of "CheerS" by ClariS is a more pleasant song with less energy, and instead gives a nice "Good work!" conclusion to the episode's current problem.  It's a satisfying listen, worth repeats to moments of unwinding, like after a hard day's work.


Personal Enjoyment:


Hataraku Saibou was never a show that I really had on my radar when I first heard about it.  Through virtue of the internet spreading the first episode like wildfire, it eventually became one of those things that just ended up on my list, and eventually something that I really looked forward to watching every week. 


Suffice to say, Hataraku Saibou was a very enjoyable (and educational) experience that was one of those episodic romps that was worth the time invested into it.  Hearing Hanakana scream at the top of her lungs as AE3083 was running away from a different pathogen every week was somehow funny every time, and the show's consistent quirkiness left me without many complaints to make since I enjoyed every episode regardless of what it was about.  True the mini arcs and humanization of blood cells did give me a bit of an existential crisis given the fact that the show manages to get the audience to pity CANCER of all diseases, but all in all, definitely a fun watch. 


A definite recommendation for those wanting something truly unique in their anime watching experience.

Well LA learned alot about the body...in all it's crazy bloody glory way, who says that anime can't be educational?
Hataraki Saibou is about the body and all the functions it does in a daily basis. Hataraku Saibou follows AE3803, a red blood cell with no sense of direction where she continuously gets ambushed by germs, viruses and bacteria where U-1146, a white blood cell comes in to take the threat down. Hataraku Saibou's narrative structure mainly follows AE3803 as she goes through some events in the body that is daily for us but a MAJOR event life threatening event in the body, be it heatstroke, bacteria infesting the body, circulation and even dealing with the early phases of cancer!


For the most part we do get some level of development when it comes to AE3803 and U-1146, mainly of how they met as well as the typical "they knew each other in childhood" as well. These two gets the most growth mainly to due them being the narrative focus of many episodes, we of course get to see the functions of other cells in our body with some development form them as well, like Killer T Saibou voiced by Daisuke Ono, Macrophage voiced by Kikuko Inoue and the Platelets voiced by Maria Naganawa who are pretty much in every episode, with some one off episode cells like Eosinophil voiced by M.A.O and NK Saibou voiced by Toa Yukinari.


Hataraku Saibou by all means and purposes anthropomorphize our body's cells and tells us useful information about body with great amount of accuracy which is helped by the narrator voiced by Mamiko Noto giving us the information about each cell every episode (though yes, the narrator repeats ALOT of the information we already know at times, making her sometimes repetitive but for someone who isn't exactly a biologist or a doctor no less helps even with it's repetitiveness and gives us information on hand as to what's going on). Hataraku Saibou by all means makes learning about the body and how it functions both cool and educational to say the least.


Hataraku Saibou's atmosphere for the most part has the moe aesthetic towards itself especially with some of the cells like the Platelets, red blood cells and Macrophage BUT also goes JOJO levels of crazy action that comes it's way, from the blood-hungry white blood cells to the much more buff Killer T cells and finally the Macrophage cells which perfectly sums up what Hataraku Saibou is like...moe silk yet has steel underneath. 


The animation done by David Production also easily makes the comparison to Jojo's and it quite obviously shows but David Production didn't skimp on the production value of this anime, being rather detailed and sure it has some reusable content, but nonetheless from the vibrant atmosphere, distinct character designs, the crazy bloody filled action and the sheer amount of various destruction of our body in animated form is grand to say the least. David Production outdid themselves!


As for voice acting, the entire voice cast is great and LA really didn't have a problem with ANY of the cast members. This might be because of so many well known voice actors in this anime such as Kana Hanazawa, Kikuko Inoue, Saori Hayami, M.A.O, Mamiko Noto, Aya Endou, Tomokazu Sugita, Tomoaki Maeno and Maria Naganawa and if LA had to give MVP, then....Tomoaki Maeno as U-1146 and Kana Hanazawa as AE3803.


Hataraku Saibou takes looking into the human body and makes it both funny, action packed and more precisely accurate and LA really liked it and even if it has an episodic format to itself and some running gags, that is a small determent to an anime that's this bombastic, educational or not, Hataraku Saibou is a good anime, from it's characters, episodic plot, well animated and voice acted and the daily chaos our body through shown in animated form.


And to think LA didn't even make one Osmosis Jones references....wait F-

Hataraku Saibou Aka Cells At Work is a very very educational but entertaining series I found myself learning about cells and how the body's works I even ended up looking up some things and reading them online 😂 oh gosh also the characters are adorable even the Killer T cells who look manly asf 👌🏼 also this show has taught me to try to live a healthy lifestyle to lessen the burden on my cells within my body I have a new found love for the cells who work 24 hours to keep my body functioning properly, I'd say anyone can watch this show enjoyit and learn from it as well it feels similar to Terraformars it's just that Terraformars is darker and more brutal than this but the both are similar you learn a lot.\n\n
