This review was edited to fit the spoilers rules of MAL.
As you can asume reading the premise this anime is not only trying to be a comedy about the human body (keyword: trying) is also an educational parody. Every single episode feature a new type of cell, showing what they can do, how they behave and why they important. These kind of ideas are usually easy to handle because are aimed to kids and they don't have a lot of critical thinking, they just want to watch some cartoons with silly characters doing silly things and if you can teach them some basic knowledge atthe same time go on but this is not for kids what probably explains why most of the characters are waifus for desperate otakus.


The main problem of Hataraku Saibou is not other than the core idea of the show because the only way known by the writers to give information is through extensive monologues full of complex medical terms that no average person knows or remember from school because is not the kind stuff you use in your daily life unless you are a doctor. This happens several times per episode, even in the middle of a battle, which by the way are not very exciting for the total lack of tension, strategies or a higher budget but these are not manly men in flamboyant clothes so what can you expect.


Comedy is another important issue. Nobody tell a joke ever or made something funny with some exceptions, all the humor is based around overreaching. Apparently most mangakas thinks that cute anime girls doing cute things are inherently funny (protip: they are not).


Talking about cute girls, the designs in this anime are so dull. These are not cells at work. These are people working in a fabric made of metal and concrete not a human body. You can made fun of how cheesy was Ozzy and Drix but at least that show had a recognizable setting.


At last, I wouldn't like to focus too much in one single episode but this is something outrageous that need to be said. [SPOILER WARNING] from this point on, of course.


In episode seven cancerogenous cells are victimized as innocent children that didn't asked to be created, tha are merciless hunted by the other cells, called by names and hated without reason.


So I don't know if you already knew this but… cancer kills. A lot. Why would we feel bad about cancer? Even in a alternate dimension were this is less offensive, the process of spreading was showed like a sabotage operation which requires a lot of planeation, so he could desists of his vengueance at any point to show them that cancer cells can be good (I can belive I just wrote that) but no, he proved they were right by acting like what everyone expected from cancer and he was still whining whenever they called him a monster.


Hataraku Saibou is plain bad. Is too complicated to be educational, too bored to be a comedy, characters are shallow and forgettabl,e and honestly you probably watching it only for the memes. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone.

I remember growing up watching osmosis jones, then we got it in anime form. I knew once I saw the trailer, it was going to be SENSATIONAL. I am a sucker for good storytelling and characters, but I normally don't seek out science related anime. However white blood cell is so badass, I can't stop watching the show, every time I see him, it's the best day ever. I love how the anime is trying to show us how the cells in body live and work together. Every episode helped me appreciate all the work my body does on a daily basis. If you wantto learn more about your body and the processes that go on, you should definitely watch it! I love how the characters match their functions and how their personalities are interesting. Every time we got a backstory or spend time a character, the more I loved them.

Your body as a community. Everything has it's place and everyone has their own job to do. 
Educational with a lot and I do mean A LOT of attention to details this show keeps your interest through it's characters. 
Everyone has their own personality that kindda fits their role in the body and the interactions between the cells keeps you invested. 
What stands out the most in the show is the character designs. from the use of stark white in the white cells so it would stand out more when they're covered in red. to the little loose hair on our MC red blood cellthat marks her as sickle blood cell explaining why she's so in efficient at her job all without out right telling the viewer. \n\n
Different bacteria have unique designs that's both eye catching and rather close to their real life counterparts. \n\n
If you watch just one anime this summer then this is the one you should check out.

Cell's at Work at it's core is an educational Saturday morning show. Made to be more entertaining than usual with cute and colorful characters. It is fun and has a good unique premise.
I wanted to wait until the whole season is over but given the episodic nature of the show, what I think of the show right now will most likely be the same as it is when it is done. 
Overall, the show is really enjoyable. Cute characters like the Platelets will be all over anime conventions for years to come. Red and White Blood Cells will be represented plentifully too. But I feellike the art is kind of meh. Nothing exceptional but it works as it is.


The sound is nothing too special as well. It works but nothing memorable comes out of it. 


What makes the show flowing are the characters though. Pun intended. Our main red blood cell (AE3803) is clumsy but I can't find a way to hate it. White Blood Cell U-1146 is the show's main badass along with the other supporting immune cells like the Killer T, Eosinophil, and Macrophage.


I can't say the same for the villains as they are all, to put it bluntly, kind of shit. An exception might be Cancel Cell but so far he's just in an episode and a half. I hope he does show up to be the main villain at the finale or someone more interesting that what we have been given so far.


If you're still on the fence about this show, my review is not really glowing but I would very much recommend it. It is really enjoyable. Not amazing but it does what it aims to be perfectly.

Hataraku Saibou is an interesting concept, I can't think of very many other things that personified cells except for Osmosis Jones. While the idea is great, and the cast is filled with amazing and talented names even for the side characters, the execution is a bit off in later episodes.
As of now I've seen around 2/3 of the episodes they have planned for this season and I'm pretty sure the structure won't change too much over the last 1/3. Not to say it's a bad thing, but it gets a little repetitive when each and every episode is filled with a similar event just involvingdifferent side characters. 


On an educational point of view I'll probably remember more from this than I will from any of my science classes, but from an anime perspective it just lacks that deep and meaningful story-line to push it anywhere past the "good" range. If I had to compare it to another anime it would be like the first few episodes of Bleach where all Ichigo does is kill Hollows. 


Still an entertaining anime, but I wouldn't recommend to anyone who doesn't like repetitive events.

This show first attracted me because I thought it looked novel, and it was. For the first four episodes. After that I was really bored with this show. I couldn't sit through the show as the story repeated over and over with no effective change.  The stories follow a certain format. Red Blood Cell finds either a germ, white blood cell, or a friend red blood cell and then they act afraid as the immune system fight the germs or that episode. The show failed to make me care about any of the characters. The art doesn't look back but it can be reallylazy at times such as in the ED and is some walking animations.
